Situation1: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I sit cross-legged on my cushion, the familiar hush of the meditation hall settling around me. As a Buddhist, I cherish these weekly group meditations—an hour to practice mindfulness, to let go of the world’s noise. But today, my mind refuses to quiet. I remember the stack of tax documents waiting at home, organized but unfinished, and the email from the community center asking for volunteers at the free vaccine clinic this weekend. As a citizen, I know my responsibilities: pay taxes on time, help keep my community safe, show up when needed. The expectation to be present, to serve, tugs at me. Yet, the sangha expects my presence too, and I long for the peace that comes from sitting with them. My heart feels pulled in two directions—toward stillness and service, inward and outward. I close my eyes, but the tension lingers, a knot in my chest, as I wrestle with which role to honor first.
